p:
Sodium hypochlorite can be used for difficult to disinfect non‐enveloped viruses such as noroviruses. Sodium hypochlorite could inactivate Norwalk virus, a type of norovirus, at a concentration of 160 ppm after 30 s exposure, as quantified by RT‐PCR.
77 Sodium hypochlorite could also inactivate the norovirus surrogates, feline calicivirus and murine norovirus, to greater than a 5 log10 reduction of infectivity with a concentration of 2700 ppm and 1 min.
78 Sodium hypochlorite at 0.5% concentration with 1 min contact time was able to deactivate the Hepatitis A virus, while another oxidizing agent peracetic acid was unable to do so.
